heading: survey says world won't end
subheading: a brand new survey shows a third of americans expect an increase in violence and crime around new year's, but most don't think y2k will have a heavy impact.
author: joanna glasner
text: the y2k survey says: americans aren't fearing mass disaster when the calendar rolls over. according to a harris interactive survey on "y2k panic level," about a third of americans expect the date change will bring an increase in violence and crime. at the same time, only 9 percent expect public transportation to be affected, and only 14 percent anticipate y2k-related power outages.of course, that doesn't mean people aren't stocking up on emergency supplies, just in case.about 28 percent of americans say they plan to stock up on food, water, and other essentials around new year's eve. the results mark a 4 percent increase from a similar study carried out last month.researchers interpreted the survey results as an indication that americans are approaching the new year with less paranoia than one might expect given the massive hype surrounding y2k computer problems.not that y2k paranoia isn't alive and well in much of the world.
